author: danfinlay
content: We've found a breaking change in current 1559 implementations, and recommend that all clients and wallets begin providing a computed `gasPrice` field when returning Transaction objects: https://github.com/ethereum/eth1.0-apis/pull/22

author: timbeiko
content: <@!135612611923279872> is this fixed by <@!543900561460822016>'s PR? https://github.com/ethereum/eth1.0-specs/pull/251#issuecomment-886878571

author: timbeiko
content: we agreed to merge it on the last ACD

author: danfinlay
content: Yes, I think that should do. How soon will this be in client production?

author: timbeiko
content: It's already in geth, and AIUI, most if not all other client implementations

author: danfinlay
content: We were not getting this value back on ropsten over the weekend, I'll have us check again..

author: timbeiko
content: We actually agreed to this 2 calls ago, but <@!301186049323958275> was unhappy with the fact that the `gasPrice` value returned changed based on the time of the transaction (mined vs. unmined), so eventually decided to keep it, but deprecate it after the next upgrade (not London, the one after).

author: timbeiko
content: With geth?

author: danfinlay
content: Yes. For example:

author: danfinlay
content: That comes from ethers.js expecting the `gasPrice` value.

author: sky.cactus
content: My proposed fix would resolve that.

author: sky.cactus
content: And not have a long tail of bugs that wallet developers have to deal with.  üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: <@135612611923279872> You should be getting the `effectiveGasPrice` from the receipt, not the transaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: The transaction *should* only have details about the transaction itself, not its execution.  For 1559 transactions this means `maxFeePerGas` and `maxPremiumPerGas`.

author: sky.cactus
content: The receipt is the proper object for data about the transactions execution/inclusion, which includes effective gas price, block number, transaction index, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: For legacy reasons, the transaction includes a *subset* of details about the transaction's execution, but that will all hopefully go away so it is recommended you switch over to using the receipt for that class of data going forward.

author: sky.cactus
content: cc <@358385024573243393> since getting ethers moved over would go a long way.

author: ricmoo
content: I fixed the Transaction object the other day as Etherscan started returning null for `gasPrice` and it killed the CI. Easy fix though and it is out. What other info needs to change in the transaction object?

author: danfinlay
content: The issue is partly that not everyone will update immediately. We want to not break older dapps also.

author: ricmoo
content: Yeah. I tried having ethers return *something*, but it was a headache.

author: ricmoo
content: Because someone might get a transaction object to clone, change a few things in it and then send it.

author: ricmoo
content: Which will fail otherwise, since ethers forbids including both a gasPrice and maxFee*.

author: ricmoo
content: (I originally supported it as long as gasPrice = maxBaseFeePerGas, but that was also riddled with issues)

author: ricmoo
content: These are the reasons there were 12 re-implementations of 1559 in my ethers local Dev branch. Once I started using it for day-to-day, problems cropped up.

author: ricmoo
content: Actually, now that I think of it, older Dapps will break if null in returned. üò¶

author: sky.cactus
content: Ideally, you only grab things from the transaction object that are part of the actual transaction.  This means the core transaction fields and hash basically.

author: sky.cactus
content: Everything else you should be getting from the receipt.

author: danfinlay
content: By not including this info on the Transaction, we still have a breaking change.

author: sky.cactus
content: Block number, transaction index, effective gas price, etc. are all things that you should avoid trying to grab from the transaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: My counter-proposal to the PR by lightclient is to have `gasPrice == maxFeePerGas` from the transaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: This way it has a number that is not *completely* unreasonable so nothing should crash at least.

author: sky.cactus
content: And unlike the current proposal, it won't result in an incredibly hard to debug problem.

author: sky.cactus
content: The current proposal is basically, "lets create heisenbugs in every integration!"

author: ricmoo
content: Ethers checks the return types match a descriptor. For Transactions, it ensures gasPrice is a BigNumberish (something that can be converted to a bug number); for 1559 it became a allowNull(BigNumberish). But that means old versions of the lib will crash and burn.

author: ricmoo
content: We should check on Etherscan to see what they are doing then.

author: ricmoo
content: I think they are passing null.

author: danfinlay
content: I agree this is a simpler fix, I'm not sure it avoids heisenbugs in unpredictable ways.

author: ricmoo
content: Which is why the CI started failing.

author: robocopsgonemad3303
content: i find it pretty conceptually easier to only include things in the Transaction that were there as signed. Everything else is more appropriate to be found in the receipt.

author: sky.cactus
content: At the least it would make it so behavior doesn't change depending on when you observe the transaction.  There will still be bugs, but they will be consistently reproducible (easy to fix).

author: ricmoo
content: Haha! I haven‚Äôt heard the term heisenbugs in forever. üôÇ

author: danfinlay
content: I agree this is idealistically preferable, but also I respect avoiding breaking changes.

author: danfinlay
content: This is probably a simple enough change, I would probably recommend including it on Transaction objects also, to minimize breakage.

author: sky.cactus
content: Sorry, yeah.  The proposal would be to specifically add `gasPrice: maxFeePerGas` to the returned Transaction object from stuff like `eth_getTransactionByHash`.

author: danfinlay
content: I think I can get behind that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Currently, the receipt has `effectiveGasPrice` and I think everyone agrees that is the right long term solution.  The inclusion of *something* in the `gasPrice` spot of transaction objects is just a bandaide for backward compatibility.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@135612611923279872> <@358385024573243393> What sort of end-of-life/deprecation timeline is acceptable to you two for removing some fields from returned transaction objects?

author: sky.cactus
content: I tentatively proposed "first patch after Shanghai", but it was basically a strawman for people to argue against.

author: juanblanco
content: will that not be an issue when replacing transactions, as the gas price will be populated, so the user will need to check if other fields are populated and remove that accordingly (just thinking out loud)

author: danfinlay
content: Like 18 months. And even then I'd likely have us continue to polyfill it. I'd need a good reason to remove it.

content: I mean, I support ES3. :p

content: As a maintainer of older projects it sucks when things break and basically means they don‚Äôt get fixed. The Python 3 migration finally broke my AES implementation the other day, written for 2, now one of the most popular implementations of AES has issues on some versions of Python.

author: ricmoo
content: What is currently used? gasPrice = maxFeePerGas?

author: ricmoo

author: sky.cactus
content: This is the heisenbug creator that I hate.

author: pietjepuk

author: ricmoo
content: If it was a tx being signed, the signature would be based on gasPrice. Not effective gasPrice.

author: ricmoo
content: Like gasLimit is the gas *limit*, not gasUsed.

author: sky.cactus
content: Geth *currently* does `gasPrice: maxFeePerGas` prior to inclusion, then `gasPrice: effectiveGasPrice` after inclusion.  Lightclient has a JSON-RPC spec PR that proposes all clients do that.  I argued that we should just do `gasPrice: maxFeePerGas` always, but I may lose (depends on call this week with app developers).

author: pietjepuk
content: well, but gasPrice currently _is_ what is paid

author: ricmoo
content: In that case could you add effectiveGasPrice to a tx and leave gasPrice = maxFee?

author: sky.cactus
content: `effectiveGasPrice` is on the receipt.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is where you should go for that information.

author: sky.cactus
content: The only reason 1559 transactions have a `gasPrice` field is to try to limit the number of things that hard fail.

author: ricmoo
content: I know, but if weird things happen if the effectiveGasPrice isn‚Äôt included on the tx.

author: ricmoo
content: Include both. üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem isn't "what happens for people who update their code".  It is "what happens for people who don't".

author: pietjepuk
content: when will it not be included in the tx?

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are updating code for London, then you'll just get `effectiveGasPrice` from the receipt if that is what you want.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are not updating code for London, then in theory returning *some number* in a `gasPrice` field on transaction objects will reduce the number of broken apps.

author: danfinlay
content: The thing that won me over to Micah's view was considering how an uncle could cause a `gasPrice` result to change between API calls.

author: danfinlay
content: If we know `gasPrice` will be able to return an inaccurate result post-1559, then it might as well be simple to derive.

author: ricmoo
content: I guess my question is what weird things happen if we make gasPrice = maxFee both before and after inclusion in a block?

author: sky.cactus
content: Hard to say, depends on what exactly people are doing with `gasPrice` from transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: Whatever the bugs though, those bugs will exist for anyone that looks at un-mined transactions.

author: pietjepuk
content: I will be the first to create a transaction that says maxFeePerGas = 1 gazillion, and see what breaks

author: sky.cactus
content: I suspect many things will break with that will break will break no matter what we do.

author: sky.cactus
content: Since the pending pool will have 1 gazillion regardless of path we choose.

author: ricmoo
content: I wondered that as well, but figure that if they aren‚Äôt EIP-1559-aware lots of things in the tx will break them. Intrinsic gas.

And just document what it‚Äôs behaviour is?

author: sky.cactus
content: Ethereum needs a way to pay down technical debt.  It is growing to the point where it is causing real pain across the ecosystem, so we do need some kind of EOL policy.

author: sky.cactus

author: ricmoo

author: ricmoo

author: pietjepuk
content: (off topic here, but I do hope that the weak-subjectivity thing will help in at least _clients_ being able to get rid of old cruft. Hopefully will help the protocol in doing so as well, maybe with a little help of state expiry ü§û)

author: sky.cactus
content: We just need to come to social consensus on a new genesis block.

author: sky.cactus
content: We don't actually need weak subjectivity for that.

author: sky.cactus
content: We just need everyone to agree that the hash of block X is ABCD and no one is expected to store or execute any history before that.

author: pietjepuk
content: Don't we do that every fork though?

author: sky.cactus
content: No, forks don't assert block X is hash ABCD.

author: sky.cactus
content: They just assert that as of block X, these are the new rules.

author: pietjepuk
content: Well, that's sort of what weak subjectivity sync is though right? But instead of a new genesis block, you either trust your software client or some people on the internet for a hash. I'm a bit wary of default, but the latter I'm totally fine with (querying some 3rd party services, reddit, whatever)

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, I see what you are saying.

author: sky.cactus
content: I wouldn't use the weak subjectivity point as the checkpoint for re-genesis personally.  We should use something much further back (maybe months).

author: sky.cactus
content: Enough time that any problems reaching social consensus have been hashed out.

author: p_bitfly
content: The current solution is very inconsistent with existing behavior, geth also does not alter the gas field of the tx object to reflect how much gas the tx really used, users know they need to get that value from the receipt. Why now change the behavior for the new gas price fields? Imo gasPrice should not be present for eip 1559 tx

author: p_bitfly
content: And the ecosystem should get ample time to adopt that breaking change before it goes live

author: pietjepuk
content: Something like every fork sets the block hash of the block that started the previous fork? Anyway, very offtopic here, so I'll leave it be

author: p_bitfly
content: Slapping band aids on that issue will only make it worse in the long run

author: pietjepuk
content: I take it that's a vote for `gasPrice = maxFeePerGas`? (at all times)

author: p_bitfly
content: Yes basically

author: p_bitfly
content: Ideally gasPrice should not be present in eip 1559 tx

author: p_bitfly
content: Because it‚Äôs undefined for that tx type

author: pietjepuk

author: pietjepuk
content: But exactly how/why geth chose to set the field that way, I don't know.

author: p_bitfly
content: If they fail now they will be fixed properly and downstream devs will be more attentive to breaking changes in the future

author: sky.cactus
content: They prefer "doing what users probably actually want some of the time" over "doing something consistent".

author: pietjepuk
content: Well, there were two others in here which just argued the opposite üòâ

author: sky.cactus
content: It isn't an unreasonable choice, though I personally disagree with it.

author: sky.cactus
content:
Personally, I think inconsistency is going to cause the ecosystem more pain over the long run.
They believe that never returning the value the user probably actually wants in that field will result in more pain over the long run.

author: p_bitfly
content: Then do it the other way round and convert legacy tx to the same format that eip 1559 tx use

author: p_bitfly

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: The issue isn't libraries having to support both types.  The issue is that things will break if they don't make any changes.

author: p_bitfly
content: Yes but 1559 is a breaking change in this regard

author: sky.cactus
content: We want to minimize the amount of things that break with the introduction of London.

author: p_bitfly

author: p_bitfly
content: And downstream users need to be aware of that

author: pietjepuk
content: Judging by the interactions here over the last few months, it does not really matter _when_ you roll out. People only seem to become aware two weeks prior

author: pietjepuk

author: trent_vanepps
content:
does anyone know of a written summary of this discussion (laying out the pros/cons/implications) for devs?

the only other resource I know is <@!543900561460822016>'s PR and the discussion there.

author: sky.cactus
content: FWIW, I still haven't updated by own tooling to work with 1559.  üò¨  Of all people, I probably am one of the most, if not the most, in the know about it.

author: ricmoo
content: That is not a fair attitude if I understand you properly. You shouldn‚Äôt just break every dApp in the universe over night so everyone is forced to update. Some updates take a long time, as it could be a deeply rooted dependency and all intermediate things must be updated. Ethers validates a transaction response makes sense, which has historically meant that gasPrice exists and is a valid value; so even if gas price is not used by a dapp, getTransaction would begin failing, since that requisite is no longer true. If you break backwards compatibility, you have to give time for things to migrate along.
